meta.name: description
meta.content: The 404 (Not Found) HTTP status code indicates the resource does not exist.

main.p: The 404 (Not Found) HTTP status code indicates the requested resource was not found, and no such error is known.

This is a 4xx client error because it is typically generated by clients who fill out URI templates (such as HTML forms) with names that do not exist. It might be a server error if the record is merely missing, and needs to be restored, as is the case with broken links.

This status code is used in response to methods that expect the request-URI to exist on the server, when the resource does not exist. This typically includes safe methods, and other methods that require a resource; including GET, HEAD, OPTIONS, and POST.

This status might also be used when disclosing the existence of a resource to an unauthorized user could be a security or privacy problem. If used for this purpose, authorization should be tested immediately after the resource is dereferenced, and before handling for 405 Method Not Allowed, 410 Gone, 429 Too Many Requests, and so on, so that the behavior is the same as the resource truly not existing.
Servers responding with this error code may wish to log the Referer header, if any, which can be used to troubleshoot the presence of broken links.
If the resource has merely been deleted (for example, a "deleted" flag on the database record is set), then see 410 Gone instead.

Servers may wish to keep track of links and a record of link targets that do not exist. If the request is for one of these resources, the server should provide instructions on how to create the resource, using a link rel=create-form, and should advertise the ability for clients to create the resource directly using an Allow: PUT header.

The exact contents of this error will likely vary by the namespace that the URI falls under. For example, a server might reserve URIs beginning with http://example.com/~ for usernames; so when handling requests for users that do not exist, the server may opt to theme 404 responses in a different HTML theme than the rest of the website.
A 404 Not Found or 410 Gone response indicates that the resource was not found on the server. Clients that want to know if the resource exists or not should check both of these status codes.

If the client found this resource from a link on another page, it may be an invitation for the client to create the resource. Otherwise, the user may want to inform the server operator of a broken link.

If the client generated the URI from a URI template (such as an HTML form), it means the server has not created a resource with the specified parameters yet; the client may try creating the given resource using a PUT request.

Some servers are known to hide the existence of resources until a user is sufficiently authorized to view the resource. If the server is known to require credentials, verify that the credentials work before trying other error recovery options.

dd.a: RFC 7231: HTTP/1.1 Semantics and Content §6.5.4. 404 Not Found
